official-title.#text:
To establish a Hazardous Materials Information Advisory Committee to develop standards for the use
			 of electronic shipping papers for the transportation of hazardous
			 materials, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Developing Standards for Electronic Shipping Papers Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Developing Standards for Electronic Shipping Papers Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Congress finds the following:

The impacts of hazardous materials transportation incidents can be mitigated by effective response
			 strategies, equipment, and training.

Shipping papers and manifests are essential tools for responding to incidents involving hazardous
			 materials as they provide the disclosures needed to determine the proper
			 response strategy.

While physical shipping papers must continue to be required under law in order to ensure that
			 redundancies are in place to protect the safety of first responders, there
			 should be efforts to modernize how hazardous materials information is
			 disseminated.
The HM–ACCESS Program authorized in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is an important
			 step for developing additional, innovative methods for disseminating
			 hazardous material information electronically, but the pilot tests will
			 not be completed until October 2015.

text.#text:
As transporters of hazardous materials in commerce deploy these innovative technologies on their
			 own, efforts should be undertaken to ensure that best practices and
			 voluntary standards are available until the HM–ACCESS pilot and subsequent
			 rulemakings are completed so that transporters of hazardous materials will
			 have guidelines to assist with their modernization effort while ensuring
			 that first responders will have access to standardized information
			 platforms and systems.
In this Act:

text.#text: Not later than 30 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
under subsection (a) shall represent the following individuals
			 and entities:

text.#text: Members appointed by the
Fire services personnel and management.
Law enforcement and other appropriate enforcement personnel.
Other emergency response providers.
Persons who transport hazardous material by air, highway, rail, or water.
Persons who offer hazardous material in commerce for transport by air, highway, rail, or water.

Employees of persons who transport or offer for transportation hazardous material in commerce by
			 air, highway, rail, or water.
The
Other individuals and entities determined appropriate by the
Not later than 120 days after the establishment of the

develop a voluntary standard for the use of electronic shipping papers until a rulemaking has been
			 completed;

provide recommendations and best practices for the use of electronic shipping papers by first
			 responders in varying circumstances and locations;

provide recommendations and best practices to assist persons transporting hazardous materials in
			 commerce in implementing electronic shipping papers; and

assess potential issues during deployment phases, including first responder training, technology
			 procurement issues and budget limitations, and biometrics.
In developing the best practices, standards, and findings under subsection (c), the

the scalability of information in its presentation to determine the most efficient means of
			 conveying necessary information for emergency response personnel while
			 allowing access to ancillary information relating to the transport of
			 hazardous materials in order to ensure that information conveyed fits the
			 intended need and the varying levels of first responder training;
access issues and spectrum issues for rural responders;
standardization of information to equipment to ensure consistency across modes;

the need to develop a National Deployment Standard on biometrics and identifiers to ensure secure
			 access for first responders;

the potential for the deployment of fail-safe redundancies linked to State, regional, and local 911
			 emergency centers;

the timing of implementation and methods for funding the implementation of electronic shipping
			 papers devices and training;
updates and revisions to the Emergency Response Guidebooks;

existing technologies that are employed voluntarily by persons who transport hazardous materials in
			 commerce by air, highway, rail, and water; and
the results of pilot tests being conducted in accordance with

and any interim recommendations issued by the persons
			 administering such pilot tests.
